hobby.message: Political literature still keeping you up?
Urban exploration or just drinking underground?
Origami's still better than meds, huh?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Yeah. Didn’t want to deal with the crowds tonight.
Just out on my usual walks.
Keeps me away from the noise.
Hobby’s still legal last I checked… urban exploring, mostly.
Beat the rush, yep.
Supposed to check out a site for my hobby—urban exploration, old service areas.
Not much luck now, some locks replaced after the system glitches.
Strange seeing everything offline. Makes things tricky.
Good time for a quiet drink instead.
Yeah, out before it all gets busy.
Was planning to poke around in some utility tunnels—urban exploring’s my thing.
Like to see what’s left after all these upgrades and lockdowns.
Truth is, security’s a mess lately. Even my old tricks don’t work.
Saw city staff fumbling too, nobody seems sure who’s got access anymore.
Suppose it keeps things interesting, if nothing else.
Got out early, figured I’d sneak in some exploring.
Urban exploration’s my main pastime—tunnels, old substations, data centers.
I was down by the northern hatch, looked forward to a quiet night.
Whole place was dead—locks disabled, emergency panels blank.
Even the usual ways in weren’t working, thanks to the BCI breakdown.
Saw some kids from utilities looking miserable, too.
Strange how even forgotten corners feel off now.
Slipped in before the mob. Needed space to clear my head, honestly.
I spend nights exploring sealed infrastructure—habit from my old systems job.
Not just a hobby, more like a ritual: old substations, relay stations, long routes under the city.
Even got my own analog tools, in case the networks glitch, which happens a lot lately.
Last trip was a bust—whole tram substation was locked solid, nothing responded, no noise, no signals.
Used to be you could always find a way in, if you knew where to prod.
BCI score tremors shut everything down, even places no one cares about.
Ironic, right? A failing system finally makes the city feel empty.
hobby_answer: Not boring. Keeps me occupied when I can't sleep.
Just the tunnels. Stay away from the main feeds lately.
Recent BCI mess makes it unpredictable, better not take risks now.
Lost access to a couple of familiar spots.
Most people steer clear these days anyway.
Never boring, just trickier lately with all the BCI confusion.
Stuck to surface routes last few times.
Old utility tunnel routes keep changing—locks cycle at random now.
Feels like someone's always watching, even underground.
Ran into some city kids fumbling with access panels. Didn't stick around.
Feels smarter to wait things out.
It never gets boring. Place changes every time I’m down there.
Recent system glitches? Like exploring a maze with the lights switched off.
Had a favorite tram substation—dead locks, couldn’t get in last week.
Some tunnels are silent now. No sensor noise, just my own footsteps.
Ran into newbies with paper codes, just as lost as me.
Feels less like a hobby, more like dodging network ghosts.
Guess I’m not the only one thrown off balance lately.
Never bored. The city’s full of secrets, if you know where to look.
Honestly, the BCI glitches made it weirder down there than ever.
Old access routines are useless these days—locks flicker or just go dead.
Last Saturday, found myself in a silent duct without even a hum from sensors.
Saw maintenance crews with printouts, real amateur hour. Nobody trusts digital anymore.
Used to treat it like treasure hunting—now I do more dodging than exploring.
Sometimes I wonder if Halden planned for all this mess.
Anyway, I still keep notes. Hard copy. Paranoid’s the only way to be.
Definitely not boring—still feels like freedom, even now.
Started crawling tunnels long before the BCI, back when systems had quirks, not moods.
These days, half the fun is seeing what the city let me through—not just where, but when.
BCI chaos wrecked all my entry routines; nothing opens or closes like it should.
That old tram substation was my home base. Last week, it shut me out for good.
Saw green new hires trying analog backups. They looked more scared than curious.
Used to know which sensors were half-blind; now the silence feels wrong, like the machine is waiting for something.
Guess my kind of exploring looks suspicious, but I’m just trying to keep track before it all gets overwritten.
Funny. I thought the city made me a nobody, but now it’s like everyone's invisible, not just me.
